lines.speaker: Local Gif
lines.text: Welcome to GeoCity!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: Geocity... like, from... "*GeoCities*"?

lines.speaker: Local Gif
lines.text: Yes, sort of. The site data that accumulated from GeoCities' inception in 1994 till its shutdown on 26th October 2009 has become dispersed over time. It still exists, chunked out in different private, public or discarded collections across the world. You're currently in one of those archives.

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: I know this place! I think my homepage might be here somewhere...

lines.speaker: Local Gif
lines.text: mostly this is just a bunch of scattered .gifs and other things left over, but you're welcome to look around!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: hey, so...

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: don't take this the wrong way, but who's still holding on to all this stuff?

lines.speaker: Local Gif
lines.text: What do you mean?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: servers cost money, right? I mean, I'm guessing that's why Yahoo shut down GeoCities, because it wasn't viable.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: this is kind of a ghost town, but who's hosting it?

lines.speaker: Local Gif
lines.text: Oh! That'll be the Internet Archive. They've been storing an archive of as many webpages as they can crawl since 1996.

lines.speaker: Local Gif
lines.text: There's not much left of something like GeoCities otherwise, eh? Any page that goes offline without getting backed up – poof!

lines.speaker: Local Gif
lines.text: Gone forever.

lines.speaker: Local Gif
lines.text: Anyhow, their servers are up north in San Fransisco, but we've probably got some bits and bobs cached down here in Redlands.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: so how many webpages is that, if it's not just GeoCities they're storing?

lines.speaker: Local Gif
lines.text: They've got nearly 70+ petabytes of data tucked away!

lines.speaker: Local Gif
lines.text: And it's not just sitting there, either – their server gets about 2k requests a second.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: that's...

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: "hello"

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: yeah.

lines.speaker: Local Gif
lines.text: Well, if you weren't quite so human, those numbers wouldn't spook you!

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: Hey, you guys! I really think my homepage is in here somewhere!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: really?

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: Yes, really! I bet one of these .gifs know the way, maybe if we try clicking on them?

TODO: add a hub here with a bunch of clickable gifs

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: Wow, this is incredible, I'm finally reunited with my homepage!

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: Be still my frames, I forgot she put me on page one of the Name Animations examples.

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: I barely remembered I had neighbors! Should I get something for Emmy and Emily?

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: well, I don't really know what to get a gif as a present

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: do you have anything left of the food from earlier, or did you give it all to the orb?

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: Oh, I know!

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: The blinkies page had some great flower gifs. I'm sure they'd love those.

lines.speaker: Karen
lines.text: You folks have a safe rest of your trip. Thanks for your help!

lines.speaker: notice
lines.text: Karen goes home.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: bye, Karen.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: speaking of home...

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: yeah, good point. we're back on land, so swimming was already out of the question, but who's taking us from here?

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: howdy!

lines.speaker: Box
lines.text: "hello"

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: (good timing)

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: my name's Michael.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: I'm guessing Michael's related to Mike and Mikey?

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Those two are my cousins. Hey, if you know those two, you must be alright!

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Let me know if you want a tour though the mines anytime!

TODO: HEAD DOWN TO THE MINES WITH MICHAEL?
loadgif goes here, but only 1 second long

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: say, Michael?

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Hm?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: that gif by the old GeoCities cache was telling us about how big the Internet Archive is.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: I don't even know how to think about 70 petabytes. That's so much information.

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: how does that even *work?*

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: is that, like, more than I could expect from an average data center? less?

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Oh, you want to talk infrastructure?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: I guess?

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Let me *tell* you about some infrastructure!

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Most data centers don't actually tell us anything about themselves.

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Security reasons, supposedly, but I can't *bear* such a complete lack of transparency.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: (don't you live underground?)

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: So nearly everything is based on guesswork, and the few details we *are* given, like data center wattage and the size of the data center's building.

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: But the Internet Archive?

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Since they're a library and a public service, they're more open with what gear they're sportin'.

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Get a load of this beauty! As of this conversation, each of these vertical racks holds about 10 individual servers.

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Each individual server is a size that could handle somewhere between 24-36 hard drives, and the Archive is slowly switching as many of their drives over to 16 TB drives as they can.

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: So every single one of those blocks could represent as much as 512 terabytes, meaning a single rack could hold as much as 5 petabytes.

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Not every server is equipped the same, so some of them are likely less than this. But to support their current storage maximum of 200 PB, that means they have at least 40 racks worth of servers.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: that's... a lot of storage

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: not to get blue about this, but... how much power do all those servers take?

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Well!

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: If we've got at least 40 racks with 10 servers each, that's 400 servers in total.

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: The power needed for the size of server the IA uses seems to clock in around 1200 – 1400 watts these days.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: so, something like 1300 watts per server, 400 times...

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: If the whole center is operating at 100% all day, it's about 525000 watts per hour, so about 12.6 kWh per day.

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: That's about 378,000 kWh per month, though it looks much better as 378 megawatt hours a month!

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: and how much do I use!?

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: You? Oh, the average US home uses about 10.7kWh per year.

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: they use more in a *day* than I do in a *year?*

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Well, are you providing an international service and/or hosting one of the internet's 200 favorite websites?

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: I guess not...

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: I'm sure that seems like a lot, but if you want a comparison, the average hyperscale data center – the kind Google, Amazon, and Microsoft house – has a power draw of about 30 mWh.

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: So, 21.6 gigawatts hours a month, for comparison.

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Heck, there are a few data centers in Inner Mongolia that run about 150 mWh, or 108 gWh hours per month!

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Really makes your head spin!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: spinning, for sure...

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: hey, can we head down into the mines? I think I need a breather from all these numbers.

TODO: hub goes here, pathid of 'server-thoughts', with options: 'Michael has more thoughts' (michael-thoughts), 'moral panic' (moral-panic), 'keep moving' (to-manhattan)

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Say, did you know that the world's 18 million servers use an estimated 200 to 500 terawatt hours per year?

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: That's somewhere between 1% and 1.5% of global power consumption!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: Michael!! Breather!!

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Fine, fine.

lines.speaker: Michael
lines.text: Kids these days!

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: hey, so...

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: yeah?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: are we, like... *against* the Internet Archive existing?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: it's an important service, but that's a *lot* of power

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: I mean, in the scheme of things, I guess it's small potatoes compared to those Google data centers

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: you know?

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: and it's a service that stands for information freedom and accountability, and those are both important too

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: yeah, I feel the same way

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: everything does have to come with some kind of cost, good or bad

lines.speaker: Zak
lines.text: I wonder how much larger Wikipedia's data centers must be?

lines.speaker: Becky
lines.text: ugh!!

todo: button that reads 'CAN WE GET THIS SHOW ON THE ROAD?'
